Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continental-Scale Monitoring, Modeling and Forecasting of Phenological Responses to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
The term phenology describes both the seasonal rhythms of plants and animals, and the study of these rhythms. Plant phenological processes, including, for example, when leaves emerge in the spring and change color in the autumn, are highly responsive to variation in weather (e.g. a warm vs. cold spring) as well as longer-term changes in climate (e.g. warming trends and changes in the timing and amount of rainfall). An interdisciplinary team, comprised of ecologists, geographers, and computer scientists, will develop a continental-scale observational network to study relationships between phenology and climate. Specifically, digital cameras posting live imagery to the Internet (webcams) will be used to monitor spring "green up" and autumn "brown down" of vegetation in different ecosystems across the United States.

This project addresses several grand challenge questions in ecology, particularly with respect to understanding and forecasting the impacts of climate change on plants and ecosystems. This project will develop predictions of how phenology may be affected by future climate change, and will quantify how future changes in phenology may impact some of the services that society derives from natural and managed ecosystems, such as agricultural crops, forest products, and clean water. In addition, the data produced from this project will be used improve the representation of phenological processes in large-scale climate models, which will help to reduce uncertainties in future climate forecasts. This project includes research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate-level students, and interdisciplinary training for two postdoctoral research associates. Summer interns in the Harvard Forest Research Experience for Undergraduates program, sponsored by NSF, will be engaged directly in this project, and collaboration both with the Harvard Forest LTER Schoolyard program and the USA National Phenology Network, will foster involvement of citizen scientists. By highlighting phenology as a tangible example of the biological impacts of climate change, these outreach efforts will raise public awareness about the environmental challenges facing humanity in the 21st Century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PI Richardson, Co-Is Friedl and Frolking: MSB Program, Collaborative Research: Continental-Scale Monitoring, Modeling and Forecasting of Phenological Responses to Climate Change, EF-1065029 (PI Andrew Richardson; Co-I Sandra Henderson, NEON), EF-1064614 (Co-I Mark Friedl), EF 1065074 (Co-I Steve Frolking), EF 1065734 (Co-I Robert Pless).

 

Our project tackled understanding vegetation phenology as a multi-scale phenomenon. We integrated ground observations on individual organisms, repeat digital photography at the canopy scale, and satellite data at pixel-to-regional scales, to test and improve phenological theory and models. We focused our analyses on interactions between climate change, phenology, and ecosystem function.

Data from the PhenoCam Network, which uses imagery from digital cameras to track vegetation phenology at high temporal resolution, were critical to our success. Through this project the PhenoCam network evolved into a continental-scale phenological observatory spanning the major biomes and ecoregions of North America. With a canopy-scale perspective, but the capacity to resolve individual organisms, the PhenoCam approach provides a direct link between on-the-ground monitoring by human observers and satellite-based monitoring at comparatively coarse spatial and temporal resolution. PhenoCam data and imagery are now publicly available, in near real time, through http://phenocam.sr.unh.edu.

We developed improved models of phenology, and associated theory regarding its environmental drivers. For example, our work demonstrated that when multi-year PhenoCam data from a broad spatial domain are used as constraints, the resulting phenological models are robust in both space and time. We have also shown the important role that photoperiod and/or winter chilling play in phenological responses to environmental variability, supporting the hypothesis that “internal controls” may limit the advancement of spring phenology under future warming.

We made fundamental contributions to understanding the impact of phenology on ecosystem biogeochemical cycling. For example, we used process-based modeling to investigate how future changes in phenology arising from climate change may impact ecosystem function. We investigated the impact of phenological shifts on fluxes of CO2 and water in temperate deciduous forests, projecting increased ecosystem productivity and ecosystem carbon storage over the next century, as well as increased transpiration and reduced water yield. And, using a model that couples ecosystem carbon and water dynamics, we modeled grassland responses to environmental change: simulations over the entire North American grassland biome suggest that despite increasing aridity, future climate change may actually enhance grassland productivity because phenological shifts towards earlier spring emergence and delayed autumn senescence more than compensate for drought-induced reductions in summertime productivity. These papers have important implications for ecosystem management, and show how phenology is a direct driver of ecosystem services with significant socioeconomic value. 

Our project contributed to the development of human resources through education and training of next-generation researchers, including 7 postdocs, 5 undergraduate students, and 8 Harvard Forest summer REUs from geographically, ethnically, and culturally diverse institutions. We have shared our research with the scientific community through 50 peer-reviewed papers and book chapters and over 100 presentations at conferences, workshops, and departmental seminars. Many of these have been led or presented by students and postdocs.

In addition, we developed several activities designed to inform and educate the general public about phenology and climate change. In collaboration with NEON’s Education and Public Engagement team we developed the online crowdsourcing program Season Spotter, in which over 20,000 citizen science volunteers participated in classifications and annotation of PhenoCam imagery. Through our collaboration with NEON, we also developed and publicly released K-12 educational materials and lesson plans focused on phenology that leverage data exploration and visualization tools available on the PhenoCam web page. Finally, we shared our science with the general public through interaction and communication with members of the media; this resulted in coverage of our project in a diverse array of print, video and online media outlets.
